page.title: 06LANDSCAPE
page.content: The most obvious feature of this block is the River Bogie which meanders at 150/160m above sea level along the western edge.At periods of thaw or heavy rainfall the banks are widely flooded causing some erosion. It is spanned by two bridges (for one see LOCAL HISTORY).The other built in 1884 is at the entrance to the village from the A97.The Aberdeen-Inverness railway & the A97 also lie along this valley. The land rises fairly steeply eastward of this valley,reaching 420m at the Hill of Corskie in the north-east,and 434m (the highest point) in the south- east at Knockandy Hill. Disused slate quarries (from one came the slates for Barmoral Castle) are all around this sector,especially on Corskie Hill.One quarry close to its summit is still used to extract hard- core for the Forestry roads.
